questions.question: Future perfect tense can be used to make predictions about completed actions in the future.
questions.explanation: The future perfect tense is used to describe actions that will be completed by a certain time in the future, which can include predictions.

questions.question: Which sentence uses future perfect tense correctly?
options: a) I will have finished my homework by 8 PM tonight.
b) She has finished her homework by 8 PM tonight.
c) They had finished their homework by 8 PM tonight.
d) We have had finished our homework by 8 PM tonight.
questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses 'will have' + past participle to describe an action that will be completed by a specific future time.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: I _______ (never/try) sushi before last night's dinner.
questions.explanation: This sentence requires past perfect tense to describe an action (or lack of action) before another past event.

questions.question: Present perfect tense uses 'had' + past participle.
questions.explanation: Present perfect tense uses 'have/has' + past participle, not 'had'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: By the time we reach the airport, the plane _______ (take off).
questions.explanation: This sentence requires future perfect tense to describe an action that will be completed by a specific future time.

questions.question: Past perfect tense is formed using 'have/has' + past participle.
questions.explanation: The past perfect tense is formed using 'had' + past participle, not 'have/has'.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the present perfect tense correctly?
options: a) I have went to the store yesterday.
b) She has gone to the store three times this week.
c) They have go to the store every day.
d) We has been to the store last month.
questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses 'has' + past participle to describe a completed action with current relevance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Before I moved to this city, I _______ (never/see) snow.
questions.explanation: This sentence requires past perfect tense to describe an action (or lack of action) before another past event.

questions.question: Future perfect tense can describe actions that will be in progress at a specific time in the future.
questions.explanation: Future perfect tense describes actions that will be completed by a specific time in the future, not actions in progress.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: By next summer, I _______ (learn) how to swim.
questions.explanation: This sentence requires future perfect tense to describe an action that will be completed by a specific future time.

questions.question: Present perfect tense can be used to describe actions that are still ongoing.
questions.explanation: Present perfect tense can describe actions that started in the past and are still ongoing in the present.

questions.question: Which sentence uses past perfect tense correctly?
options: a) I had eaten lunch when she called.
b) She has eaten lunch when I called.
c) They will have eaten lunch when we call.
d) We have had eaten lunch when you called.
questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses 'had' + past participle to describe an action completed before another past action.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: They _______ (live) in this house for ten years now.
questions.explanation: This sentence requires present perfect tense to describe an ongoing action that started in the past and continues to the present.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: She _______ (already/finish) her homework when I called.
questions.explanation: This sentence requires past perfect tense to show an action completed before another past action.

questions.question: Present perfect tense always uses 'have' for all subjects.
questions.explanation: Present perfect uses 'have' for I/you/we/they and 'has' for he/she/it.
